messages.text: <@U02JFCNHKHB> has joined the channel
<@UM3V8V1NK> has joined the channel
<@U37KPJ30D> has joined the channel

Immediate priority: ARA is using a chatbot service to create cases. The service is called LiveChatNow. We need to assess how complicated it is to move this to a new Salesforce instance. 

LiveChatNow hosts everything that has to do with the bot and provides integration with SF. Creating cases and handling status updates are a matter of field mappings and configurations on the LiveChatNow side, and the service will take care of everything else. 

We need to know: 

1. What exists on the SF end to support this
2. How easy it is to move this to a new SF instance 
3. What is the rough timeline for getting this moved
Need this by mid day tomorrow.

elements.text:
Immediate priority: ARA is using a chatbot service to create cases. The service is called LiveChatNow. We need to assess how complicated it is to move this to a new Salesforce instance. 

LiveChatNow hosts everything that has to do with the bot and provides integration with SF. Creating cases and handling status updates are a matter of field mappings and configurations on the LiveChatNow side, and the service will take care of everything else. 

We need to know:
What exists on the SF end to support this
How easy it is to move this to a new SF instance
What is the rough timeline for getting this moved
Need this by mid day tomorrow.

messages.text: <@UM3V8V1NK> <@U37KPJ30D>
Noted <@U02JFCNHKHB>.

elements.text: Noted

messages.text:
*<@U02JFCNHKHB> Current State & Migration Summary*
• The current LiveChatNow setup is primarily supported on the Salesforce side through *Case-centric configuration*, rather than custom code.
• LiveChatNow created interactions result in *Case records* in Salesforce, with the Case object carrying all related information through a defined set of *standard and custom fields*.
• *Assignment rules and queues* are used to route these cases to the appropriate support teams.
• *Omni-Channel routing* is enabled and used to distribute cases to agents based on *presence, capacity, and routing configuration*.
• There are *6–7 Screen Flows built on the Case object* that support custom agent interactions. These flows are *UI-driven*, do not represent backend automation, and are *not triggered by LiveChatNow API calls*. However, they must be reviewed and deployed to the new Salesforce instance to ensure continued functionality and to avoid interference with API-based case creation.
• Importantly, *no Apex triggers, custom code, or programmatic automation* have been identified in the current production org. This significantly reduces migration risk, as the entire setup is *metadata-driven and portable*.
• From an integration perspective, *LiveChatNow is a third-party application* fully hosted outside Salesforce. It connects to Salesforce using *standard APIs (REST/SOAP)* via a dedicated *integration user*. Salesforce acts purely as a downstream system for *case creation, updates, and routing*.
• To move this setup to a new Salesforce instance, *all Salesforce-side configuration must be deployed*, including:
    ◦ Case-related fields
    ◦ Assignment rules and queues
    ◦ Email-to-case
    ◦ Omni-Channel routing configurations
    ◦ Page layouts and console components
    ◦ Screen Flows and related dependencies
    ◦ Integration user and permission sets
• Once the new Salesforce instance is ready, the *out-of-the-box API URLs and authentication details* for the new org must be updated in LiveChatNow. This includes repointing LiveChatNow to the new Salesforce endpoints and *reauthorizing the integration user*.
• The overall effort is focused on *deploying metadata and updating integration endpoints*, rather than rebuilding functionality.
• Moving LiveChatNow to a new Salesforce instance is a *controlled, low-to-moderate effort activity*, with an estimated timeline of *approximately 1 to 1.5 weeks*.

messages.text: It is not only the LiveChatNow integration, any Case-centric configuration around it (such as Email-to-Case, routing, queues, Omni-Channel, and flows) must also be considered as part of the move. If some of these Case-centric configurations are not required in the new production setup, the overall effort could reduce significantly.

messages.text:
Notes from working sessions with Darren yesterday:

• 20 UE Sales/Service Cloud licenses (expanding to 26)
• Sales Cloud
    ◦ Shadow IT configured
    ◦ Using opportunities
    ◦ Integrated Docusign
    ◦ Not proposing any changes until Summer
    ◦ Web to lead – future goal (we have a lot of forms today going straight to email, could be cases – tbd)
• Service Cloud
    ◦ Shadow IT configured
    ◦ Service Console is being used
    ◦ One primary queue in use
    ◦ We do segment reports by “sister organization”, but this is currently flagged on the case as a picklist value
    ◦ We have 5 individually branded organizations and customer care email addresses - the same service team handles all cases
        ▪︎ Case Origin = Chat
            • LiveChatNow for chat
            • Chats are either double-data entered, or simply chats come in and new cases are created without linkage to contacts and accounts
            • No issue continuing to use this for now. eventually would like to move over to salesforce, but no timeline
        ▪︎ Case Origin = Email
            • Standard outlook rules redirecting to Service cloud
        ▪︎ Case Origin = Phone
            • Cases are entered with minimal data - without linkage to contacts and accounts
    ◦ IVR – current IVR is not integrated, future goal
    ◦ Web to case – would like to explore, future
*At Fonteva launch (3/16)*
• Service
    ◦ Reconfigure outlook redirect rules to direct cases to this new environment
    ◦ Need 4 queues – Customer Care, Accounting, IT, Sales (Data Management)
        ▪︎ Basic case usage assigned by inbound email, assigned via Fonteva process or via case transfer ownership/escalation
        ▪︎ These are already created in current Prod, but there are a bunch of other old stuff that appears to be unused
        ▪︎ Service console would need to be ported as it is today
    ◦ Any existing open cases would be worked from the old environment
• Sales
    ◦ No change
*Post Fonteva Launch (March – July)*
• Clean up and migrate historical Case data
• Reconfigure Sales Cloud
    ◦ Re-implement Docusign
• Clean up and migrate historical Opportunity data, Docusign contracts, etc.

messages.text:
Immediate scope:
• LiveChatNow integration user
• API access & endpoints
• Case object (bare minimum fields used by LiveChatNow)
• Any hard dependency required for case insert/update
Explicitly out of scope for now:
• Contact / Account linkage
• Screen Flows
• Omni-Channel
• Email-to-Case
• Business process improvements
Those become post-cutover evaluation items, not migration blockers.

messages.text:
<@U37KPJ30D> Also found that when livehelpnow creates a Case, it is identified by *Case Origin = Chat* and *Type = Question*. livehelpnow only populates the basic Case fields such as *Subject, Description, SuppliedName, and SuppliedEmail*.
After the Case is created, Salesforce triggers the *“Case Created Add Contact”* Flow, which invokes the Apex class *CreateContactForCaseHelper*. This Apex class creates a new Contact using the visitor’s name and email, associates it with the Account named *“ARA Customer Care,”* and then updates the Case to link both the Contact and the Account.

Additionally,  identified a few users who have permission sets assigned, and this has been updated in the sheet.

elements.text: Also found that when livehelpnow creates a Case, it is identified by
Case Origin = Chat
and
Type = Question
. livehelpnow only populates the basic Case fields such as
Subject, Description, SuppliedName, and SuppliedEmail

.
After the Case is created, Salesforce triggers the
“Case Created Add Contact”
Flow, which invokes the Apex class
CreateContactForCaseHelper
. This Apex class creates a new Contact using the visitor’s name and email, associates it with the Account named
“ARA Customer Care,”

and then updates the Case to link both the Contact and the Account.

Additionally,  identified a few users who have permission sets assigned, and this has been updated in the sheet.

messages.text:
EXTERNAL EMAIL] This email was received from outside of the organization. Please be cautious opening links and report anything suspicious to the IT helpdesk.

Dear Sandbox admin,

Your new sandbox "full" is ready for use. Click <https://data-drive-3448--full.sandbox.my.salesforce.com/?un=dbailey%40usaretirement.org.new.full|https://data-drive-3448--full.sandbox.my.salesforce.com/?un=dbailey%40usaretirement.org.new.full> to log in now.

Users who were granted access to the sandbox can log in from <https://data-drive-3448--full.sandbox.my.salesforce.com/|https://data-drive-3448--full.sandbox.my.salesforce.com/> by appending ".full" to their Salesforce user logins. For example, if your login in your production account is user@company.domain, then your login for this sandbox is user@company.domain.full.

All active users of the source org have access to the sandbox, unless you used the Selective Sandbox Access feature. To keep sandboxes secure, any user that does not login within the first 60 days is automatically frozen. You can provide access to frozen users in the sandbox by unfreezing their user accounts. See Salesforce Help: "Freeze or Unfreeze User Accounts" for instructions.

To be proactively notified of incidents or maintenance impacting USA792S, subscribe to Trust Notifications. Subscription instructions here: <https://trust.salesforce.com/en/trust/trust-notification-user-guide/|https://trust.salesforce.com/en/trust/trust-notification-user-guide/>. If you are already signed up for Trust Notifications, you will need to update your subscription settings to receive notifications regarding the USA792S instance.

Thank you,

Salesforce

I know that feeling, and I’ve been there too. I don’t have a specific excuse, except that I really do need to take a step back and stop reacting, and instead start responding more thoughtfully.
Working with Abhi to get all of this mess cleared and more streamlined.
